title: Industrials Down After Inflation Data -- Industrials Roundup
description: Industrials Down After Inflation Data -- Industrials Roundup
content:
Shares of industrial and transportation companies fell after an increase in the Federal Reserve's preferred gauge of consumer prices.

Chemicals maker DuPont agreed to sell its Kevlar and Nomex materials business to Arclin, a company backed by investment firm TJC, for $1.8 billion.

The Trump administration's firing of a critic of railroad consolidation from an industry regulatory board paves the way for a merger between Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern to be approved, said analysts at brokerage TD Cowen. President Trump fired Robert Primus, a board member of the railroad regulator that is weighing the proposed megamerger. John Wood Group agreed to a boosted takeover offer from rival Sidara for roughly $280.4 million after months of talks.
summary: Shares of industrial and transportation companies fell after an increase in the Federal Reserve's preferred gauge of consumer prices. DuPont agreed to sell its Kevlar and Nomex materials business to Arclin, a company backed by investment firm T. Additionally, the Trump administration's dismissal of Robert Primus, a board member of the railroad regulator, could pave the way for a merger between Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern.
shortSummary: Shares of industrial and transportation stocks fell after a rise in consumer prices, with key deals including DuPont's $1.8 billion sale and John Wood's $40.4 million purchase of Heinic.
